fullProgramDescription: The Political Science/Public Law major at UC San Diego is offered by the Department of Political Science. It is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the role of law and the courts in the American political system. The program includes coursework in constitutional law, civil liberties, and the judicial process, as well as elective courses in related fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Political Science/Public Law major provides a foundation in the study of law and the courts, preparing students for careers in law, government, and related fields.
classHighlights: The major requires coursework in American Politics (POLI 101), Introduction to Public Law (POLI 127), and Constitutional Law (POLI 128), providing a foundation in the study of law and the courts.

Students also take courses in research methods and statistics, including Quantitative Methods in Political Science (POLI 106) and Research Methods in Political Science (POLI 205A), to develop their analytical skills.

Elective courses allow students to explore topics such as Civil Liberties (POLI 129), Judicial Politics (POLI 130), and Law and Society (POLI 131), deepening their understanding of the role of law in society.
learningOutcomes: Understand the role of law and the courts in the American political system
Analyze the impact of judicial decisions on public policy
Develop skills in research methods and statistical analysis
Apply theoretical knowledge to real-world issues in law and politics
creditRequirements: 48 upper-division units in the major; total approximately 180 quarter units
additionalInformation: The major is offered by the Department of Political Science, not Physics. Students should consult with the department for advising on the major.
